title: Joshua Chapter 10 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Joshua chapter 10 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Joshua Chapter 10 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Joshua Chapter 10.

questions.question: Who was the king of Jerusalem that feared the city of Gibeon?
options: Adonizedek
Hoham
Piram
Japhia
questions.correctAnswer: Adonizedek
questions.explanation: Adonizedek king of Jerusalem feared Gibeon because it was a great city, as stated in Joshua 10:1-2.

questions.question: Which city had made peace with Israel, causing fear among the Amorite kings?
options: Gibeon
Ai
Jericho
Makkedah
questions.correctAnswer: Gibeon
questions.explanation: The inhabitants of Gibeon had made peace with Israel, which alarmed the Amorite kings (Joshua 10:1-3).

questions.question: How many kings gathered together to make war against Gibeon?
options: Five
Three
Seven
Four
questions.correctAnswer: Five
questions.explanation: The five kings of the Amorites, including the king of Jerusalem, gathered to wage war against Gibeon (Joshua 10:5).

questions.question: What did the men of Gibeon do when they were attacked by the Amorite kings?
options: Sent a message to Joshua to come quickly and save them
Surrendered immediately
Fled to another city
Fought without asking for help
questions.correctAnswer: Sent a message to Joshua to come quickly and save them
questions.explanation: The men of Gibeon sent to Joshua at Gilgal requesting help because they were attacked by the Amorite kings (Joshua 10:6).

questions.question: What was God's command to Joshua when he was to face the Amorite kings?
options: Fear them not; I have delivered them into your hand
Retreat and wait for reinforcements
Make peace with the kings
Attack only at dawn
questions.correctAnswer: Fear them not; I have delivered them into your hand
questions.explanation: God told Joshua not to fear because He had delivered the Amorite kings into Joshua's hand (Joshua 10:8).

questions.question: How long did the sun stand still during the battle at Gibeon?
options: About a whole day
One hour
Three days
Until the evening
questions.correctAnswer: About a whole day
questions.explanation: The sun stood still in the midst of heaven and hastened not to go down for about a whole day (Joshua 10:13).

questions.question: Where did the five kings hide after their defeat?
options: In a cave at Makkedah
In the city of Jericho
On the mountains of Hebron
In the valley of Ajalon
questions.correctAnswer: In a cave at Makkedah
questions.explanation: After fleeing, the five kings hid themselves in a cave at Makkedah (Joshua 10:16).

questions.question: What did Joshua command to be done to the mouth of the cave where the five kings were hiding?
options: Roll great stones upon it and set men to guard it
Set fire to the cave
Flood the cave with water
Leave it open
questions.correctAnswer: Roll great stones upon it and set men to guard it
questions.explanation: Joshua ordered that great stones be rolled upon the cave's mouth and men be stationed there to guard it (Joshua 10:18).

questions.question: What did Joshua say to the captains of the men of war when the five kings were brought out of the cave?
options: Put your feet upon the necks of these kings
Release them
Make a treaty with them
Keep them in prison
questions.correctAnswer: Put your feet upon the necks of these kings
questions.explanation: Joshua called for the captains to put their feet upon the necks of the five kings as a sign of victory (Joshua 10:24).

questions.question: What happened to the five kings after Joshua smote them?
options: They were hanged on five trees until evening
They were released
They were sent to another land
They were imprisoned indefinitely
questions.correctAnswer: They were hanged on five trees until evening
questions.explanation: Joshua smote the kings and hanged them on five trees until the evening (Joshua 10:26).

questions.question: True or False: The LORD fought for Israel during the battle at Gibeon.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: It is stated that the LORD fought for Israel, allowing their enemies to be delivered into their hand (Joshua 10:14, 42).

questions.question: True or False: Joshua took Makkedah and spared many of its inhabitants.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua utterly destroyed Makkedah and left none remaining, as recorded in Joshua 10:28.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua fought against and took the city of Hebron after Eglon.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua passed from Eglon to Hebron and fought against it, taking the city as recorded in Joshua 10:36-37.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Joshua 10:12: Then spake Joshua to the LORD in the day when the LORD delivered up the Amorites before the children of Israel, and he said in the sight of Israel, 'Sun, stand thou still upon ______; and thou, Moon, in the valley of Ajalon.'
options: Gibeon
Jerusalem
Gilgal
Bethhoron
questions.correctAnswer: Gibeon
questions.explanation: Joshua commanded the sun to stand still upon Gibeon as stated in Joshua 10:12.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Joshua 10:43: 'And Joshua returned, and all Israel with him, unto the camp to ______.'
options: Gilgal
Makkedah
Hebron
Lachish
questions.correctAnswer: Gilgal
questions.explanation: Joshua and all Israel returned to the camp at Gilgal as recorded in Joshua 10:43.

medium.title: Joshua Chapter 10 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Joshua Chapter 10 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Joshua 10, what biblical truth would you share about trusting God in difficult battles?
options: God fights for those who trust Him and grants victory
Victory depends solely on human strength and strategy
God only helps when battles are easy
We should avoid conflicts to stay safe
questions.correctAnswer: God fights for those who trust Him and grants victory
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:8, 10:40, and 10:42 show that God fought for Israel and delivered their enemies into their hands, teaching believers to trust God's power in spiritual and physical battles.

questions.question: How does the account of Joshua praying for the sun and moon to stand still (Joshua 10:12-14) teach us about the power of prayer and God's response?
options: God listens and responds to the prayers of faith
Prayer is ineffective in urgent situations
God only responds to prayers of kings
Prayer replaces the need for action
questions.correctAnswer: God listens and responds to the prayers of faith
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:12-14 records Joshua's prayer and God's miraculous response, showing God's willingness to hear and act upon the prayers of His people who demonstrate faith and courage.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with fear when facing opposition. Based on Joshua 10, what encouragement can you offer about courage and God's promises?
options: Fear not, be strong and courageous because God delivers your enemies
Fear is natural and you should avoid confrontation
Only kings should face enemies courageously
Courage is unnecessary if you pray
questions.correctAnswer: Fear not, be strong and courageous because God delivers your enemies
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:8 and 10:25 show God telling Joshua not to fear and encouraging strength and courage, affirming that God empowers His people to overcome fear and opposition.

questions.question: How does the story of the five kings hiding in the cave and being captured (Joshua 10:16-27) teach us about integrity and obedience in leadership?
options: Leaders must act decisively and obey God's commands fully
Leaders should negotiate with enemies instead of fighting
Leaders can spare enemies if they feel merciful
Delaying action shows wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must act decisively and obey God's commands fully
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:18-27 shows Joshua following God's instructions to capture the kings and execute judgment, illustrating the importance of integrity and obedience in leadership and decision-making.

questions.question: A believer is concerned about perseverance through trials. What does Joshua 10 teach about persevering to complete the work God has given?
options: Persevere until the task is fully accomplished as God commands
Quit if the work becomes too hard
Delegate all difficult tasks to others
Only do part of the work and wait for better conditions
questions.correctAnswer: Persevere until the task is fully accomplished as God commands
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:20, 10:28-40 describe how Joshua and Israel continued their campaign until all enemies were defeated, exemplifying obedience and perseverance to fulfill God's plans.

questions.question: How can Joshua 10 teach us about humility and gratitude when God grants us success in our endeavors?
options: Give glory to God because He fights for us and grants victory
Claim all success as your own
Ignore God's role in your achievements
Take credit only for the planning and effort
questions.correctAnswer: Give glory to God because He fights for us and grants victory
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:42-43 states that Joshua took the land because the LORD God of Israel fought for Israel, highlighting the need for humility and gratitude toward God's providence and help.

questions.question: What does Joshua 10 teach about the importance of obedience to God’s commands in spiritual warfare and daily life?
options: Obedience to God's commands leads to victory and blessing
Obedience is optional and not important
Only kings need to obey God's commands
Disobedience has no consequences if you pray
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God's commands leads to victory and blessing
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:19-20, 10:40 show how obedience to God's instructions brought Israel great victories, teaching that obedience is foundational to spiritual success and daily living.

questions.question: A believer wonders how to serve others effectively in the church. Based on Joshua 10, what biblical principle can you share?
options: Be ready to act promptly and support fellow believers in times of need
Serve only when it benefits you personally
Avoid involvement in others' struggles
Wait for others to serve you first
questions.correctAnswer: Be ready to act promptly and support fellow believers in times of need
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:6-7 describes how Gibeon sent for help and Joshua quickly responded with all his mighty men, teaching believers to serve and support one another promptly and faithfully.

questions.question: True or False: According to Joshua 10, God’s miraculous help can change the natural order to accomplish His purposes.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:12-14 describe the sun standing still and the moon stopping to allow Israel to complete their battle, showing that God can intervene miraculously in nature to fulfill His plans.

questions.question: True or False: Joshua 10 teaches that God only helps those who are physically strong and courageous without any need for faith.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:8 and 10:14 emphasize that God fights for Israel and that His help is a response to faith and obedience, not merely human strength or courage.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: When the five kings were found hiding in a cave, Joshua ordered to ______ the cave's mouth and set men to keep it.
options: roll great stones upon
open wide
burn down
cover with dirt
questions.correctAnswer: roll great stones upon
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:18 states Joshua commanded to roll great stones upon the mouth of the cave and set men to guard it, showing decisive action in securing victory.

questions.question: Based on Joshua 10, how does the chapter teach us about honesty and integrity in warfare and leadership?
options: Execute just and fair judgments according to God’s commands
Use deceit and trickery to win battles
Neglect God's instructions for personal gain
Spare enemies to avoid confrontation
questions.correctAnswer: Execute just and fair judgments according to God’s commands
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:24-27 shows Joshua publicly executing the kings as God commanded, illustrating integrity and justice in leadership and warfare.

questions.question: What does the destruction of cities and kings in Joshua 10 teach about obedience to God’s will in accomplishing His purposes?
options: Complete obedience to God's commands is necessary to accomplish His will fully
Partial obedience is acceptable
Disobedience can be ignored if intentions are good
Delay in obedience is better for reflection
questions.correctAnswer: Complete obedience to God's commands is necessary to accomplish His will fully
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:28-39 describe the utter destruction of cities and kings as commanded by God, teaching that full obedience is essential in fulfilling God's purposes.

questions.question: How does Joshua 10 exemplify the virtue of stewardship in using the resources God has given us for His kingdom?
options: Using God-given strength and leadership to fully conquer and possess the land
Ignoring God’s commands and acting selfishly
Wasting resources on unnecessary battles
Waiting passively for blessings without effort
questions.correctAnswer: Using God-given strength and leadership to fully conquer and possess the land
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:39-42 show Joshua and Israel using their God-given strength and leadership to take possession of territories, illustrating faithful stewardship of God's blessings and responsibilities.

questions.question: How does the battle at Gibeon and the response of Joshua teach us about perseverance and God's timing in trials?
options: Persevere and trust God to act in His perfect timing and power
Give up when challenges seem too great
Rely only on human plans without seeking God
Delay action until all fears are gone
questions.correctAnswer: Persevere and trust God to act in His perfect timing and power
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:6-14 shows Joshua responding quickly, trusting God's promise, and God performing a miracle, teaching believers to persevere and rely on God's timing in trials.

hard.title: Joshua Chapter 10 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Joshua Chapter 10.

questions.question: Which five kings united to make war against Gibeon after it made peace with Israel?
options: The kings of Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish, and Eglon
The kings of Ai, Jericho, Gibeon, Hebron, and Lachish
The kings of Jerusalem, Ai, Jericho, Debir, and Lachish
The kings of Hebron, Jarmuth, Jericho, Ai, and Eglon
questions.correctAnswer: The kings of Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish, and Eglon
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:5 specifies these five kings as the king of Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish, and Eglon who joined forces against Gibeon.

questions.question: What is the significance of the sun and moon standing still during the battle at Gibeon?
options: It demonstrates God's intervention and control over nature to aid Israel's victory
It symbolizes the end of the Amorite kings' reign
It marks the beginning of Joshua's kingship over Israel
It is a poetic metaphor for the darkness of war
questions.correctAnswer: It demonstrates God's intervention and control over nature to aid Israel's victory
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:12-14 describes the sun and moon standing still as a miraculous event showing divine aid, emphasizing that the LORD fought for Israel.

questions.question: In the historical context of the ancient Near East, what does the act of putting feet upon the necks of the defeated kings symbolize?
options: Total submission and humiliation of the enemy
A ritual of alliance and peace
A sign of respect for defeated nobility
A gesture indicating release from captivity
questions.correctAnswer: Total submission and humiliation of the enemy
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:24 shows Joshua commanding the captains to put their feet on the kings’ necks, symbolizing complete conquest and humiliation, a common Ancient Near Eastern practice.

questions.question: How does the event of the hailstones killing more enemies than the sword relate to God's judgment themes in the Old Testament?
options: It illustrates God's direct intervention and judgment similar to plagues in Exodus
It reflects natural disaster unrelated to divine action
It shows the Amorite kings' betrayal of a covenant
It symbolizes the cleansing of Israel's enemies through fire
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates God's direct intervention and judgment similar to plagues in Exodus
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:11 parallels divine judgment motifs like the plague of hail in Exodus, demonstrating God’s power to defeat Israel’s enemies supernaturally.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Joshua 10:12-14 when Joshua commands the sun and moon to stand still?
options: A poetic hyperbole emphasizing divine aid
A historical chronicle of astronomical events
A legal covenant enactment
An allegory for Israel’s military strategy
questions.correctAnswer: A poetic hyperbole emphasizing divine aid
questions.explanation: The miraculous halting of celestial bodies in Joshua 10:12-14 is best understood as poetic hyperbole illustrating God's empowerment of Israel in battle.

questions.question: Which book outside of Joshua is referenced in relation to the sun standing still event?
options: The Book of Jasher
The Book of Psalms
The Book of Judges
The Book of Samuel
questions.correctAnswer: The Book of Jasher
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:13 explicitly mentions the Book of Jasher as containing the record of the sun standing still, showing intertextual reference.

questions.question: True or False: The five kings fled to a cave at Makkedah and were immediately executed by Joshua without delay.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:16-27 narrates how the kings hid in a cave, were sealed in by stones, and only later were brought out and executed.

questions.question: What does the repeated phrase 'he left none remaining' throughout Joshua 10 signify in the context of Israelite warfare?
options: Complete destruction as an act of divine judgment to prevent idolatry
An exaggeration for storytelling purposes
A political alliance formed with the defeated cities
A ritual to consecrate the land for Israelite settlement
questions.correctAnswer: Complete destruction as an act of divine judgment to prevent idolatry
questions.explanation: Verses like Joshua 10:28, 30, 35 emphasize total annihilation aligning with the Deuteronomic command to destroy Canaanite idolatry and prevent Israel from being influenced.

questions.question: How does Joshua 10:40-42 encapsulate the theological theme of divine assistance in Israel's conquest?
options: By stating that all kings and lands were taken because the LORD God of Israel fought for Israel
By attributing victory solely to Israel’s military skill
By emphasizing diplomatic negotiations over warfare
By describing natural disasters as the main cause of victories
questions.correctAnswer: By stating that all kings and lands were taken because the LORD God of Israel fought for Israel
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:42 explicitly attributes Israel’s comprehensive conquest to God’s direct involvement, reinforcing the theological motif of divine warrior.

questions.question: Which king came to help Lachish and was completely defeated by Joshua?
options: Horam king of Gezer
Adonizedek king of Jerusalem
Piram king of Jarmuth
Hoham king of Hebron
questions.correctAnswer: Horam king of Gezer
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:33 mentions Horam, king of Gezer, coming to aid Lachish and being defeated entirely by Joshua.

questions.question: What does the command to roll great stones upon the mouth of the cave where the kings hid symbolize in the cultural context of the Ancient Near East?
options: Preventing escape and signifying imprisonment
Marking a sacred burial site
Sealing a treaty with the kings
Preparing the cave as a temple
questions.correctAnswer: Preventing escape and signifying imprisonment
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:18 describes sealing the cave with stones to imprison the kings securely, a practice consistent with Ancient Near Eastern methods of confinement.

questions.question: How does Joshua’s encouragement to his captains to be strong and courageous reflect broader biblical themes?
options: It echoes the motif of divine empowerment found in Deuteronomy and Psalms
It indicates a new covenant with Israel’s enemies
It reflects a political strategy rather than theological encouragement
It contradicts earlier commands to rely solely on God
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes the motif of divine empowerment found in Deuteronomy and Psalms
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:25 reflects a recurring biblical exhortation to courage and strength grounded in trust in God’s help, similar to Deuteronomy 31:6 and Psalm 27.

questions.question: Which city did Joshua attack immediately after taking Makkedah, continuing the conquest campaign?
options: Libnah
Lachish
Eglon
Hebron
questions.correctAnswer: Libnah
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:29 states that after Makkedah, Joshua and Israel moved on to fight against Libnah.

questions.question: In literary terms, what structure is apparent in the sequence of city conquests narrated in Joshua 10:28-39?
options: A repetitive parallelism emphasizing total destruction
A chiasm highlighting the central conquest of Lachish
An allegory for spiritual warfare
A metaphorical journey toward Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: A repetitive parallelism emphasizing total destruction
questions.explanation: The verses systematically record each city’s capture and destruction with repeated phrases, creating a parallel structure underscoring comprehensive victory.

questions.question: How does the narrative of Joshua 10 emphasize the theme of God's faithfulness towards His covenant people?
options: By showing God fighting for Israel and granting them victory as promised
By focusing only on Israel’s military prowess
By highlighting the Amorite kings’ repentance
By portraying a compromise with the enemy kings
questions.correctAnswer: By showing God fighting for Israel and granting them victory as promised
questions.explanation: Joshua 10:14, 42 emphasize that God hearkened to Joshua’s voice and fought for Israel, reflecting fulfillment of covenantal promises.

theological.title: Joshua Chapter 10 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Joshua Chapter 10 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the reason Adonizedek king of Jerusalem feared the inhabitants of Gibeon?
options: Because Gibeon was a great city and greater than Ai
Because Gibeon had many allies in the mountains
Because Gibeon had a large army of chariots
Because Gibeon had fortified walls like Jericho
questions.correctAnswer: Because Gibeon was a great city and greater than Ai
questions.explanation: Adonizedek feared greatly because Gibeon was a great city, one of the royal cities, and greater than Ai (Joshua 10:2). This shows the recognition of God’s providence in Israel’s conquest as they face formidable enemies (Exodus 23:27, Deut 7:1, Josh 11:6, Neh 4:7).

questions.question: Who were the five kings that joined Adonizedek to attack Gibeon?
options: The kings of Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish, and Eglon
The kings of Jericho, Ai, Gibeon, Bethel, and Hazor
The kings of Egypt, Moab, Ammon, Edom, and Amalek
The kings of Shechem, Shiloh, Mount Ephraim, Bethel, and Gilgal
questions.correctAnswer: The kings of Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish, and Eglon
questions.explanation: The coalition was formed by the kings of Jerusalem, Hebron, Jarmuth, Lachish, and Eglon to attack Gibeon (Joshua 10:5). This alliance shows the human opposition to God’s plan, a common biblical theme (Psalm 2:2, Isa 8:9-10, Acts 4:26-27, Rev 17:12).

questions.question: How did the LORD assure Joshua about the coming battle against the Amorite kings?
options: Fear them not; for I have delivered them into thine hand
Gather your forces and wait for my command
Build an altar for sacrifice before the battle
Send a messenger to negotiate peace
questions.correctAnswer: Fear them not; for I have delivered them into thine hand
questions.explanation: God told Joshua not to fear because He had delivered the enemy into Joshua’s hand (Joshua 10:8). This affirms God's sovereignty and faithfulness to His covenant people (Deut 20:4, 1 Sam 17:47, 2 Chron 20:15, Heb 13:6).

questions.question: What miraculous sign did Joshua command the LORD to perform during the battle?
options: Sun stand still upon Gibeon and Moon in the valley of Ajalon
Rain fire and brimstone upon the enemy
Part the Jordan River for escape
Cause the walls of enemy cities to crumble
questions.correctAnswer: Sun stand still upon Gibeon and Moon in the valley of Ajalon
questions.explanation: Joshua commanded the sun and moon to stand still to prolong the day so Israel could complete their victory (Joshua 10:12-13). This reveals God's control over creation and His willingness to intervene for His people (Psalm 74:16-17, Isaiah 38:8, Habakkuk 3:11, Revelation 10:1-2).

questions.question: What does the event of the sun standing still teach about God's attributes?
options: God is sovereign over time and nature
God prefers indirect intervention
God is limited by natural laws
God only acts through human armies
questions.correctAnswer: God is sovereign over time and nature
questions.explanation: The sun and moon standing still demonstrates God's absolute sovereignty over creation and time (Joshua 10:13-14). This supports biblical teaching of God's omnipotence (Psalm 104:19, Colossians 1:17, Hebrews 1:3, Revelation 4:8).

questions.question: What role did God play in delivering the Amorites into Israel’s hands?
options: The LORD fought for Israel
Israel’s military strength was the key
The Amorites fled due to famine
God gave Israel the weapons
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD fought for Israel
questions.explanation: The text explicitly states the LORD fought for Israel (Joshua 10:14, 42), emphasizing divine agency in victory rather than human effort alone (Exodus 14:14, Deuteronomy 20:4, 2 Chronicles 20:15, Romans 8:31).

questions.question: Where did the five kings hide after their defeat by Israel?
options: In a cave at Makkedah
In the city of Jerusalem
By the river Jordan
In the mountains of Hebron
questions.correctAnswer: In a cave at Makkedah
questions.explanation: The defeated kings fled and hid in a cave at Makkedah (Joshua 10:16). This highlights the desperation of those who oppose God's people and a motif of hiding before judgment (Genesis 3:8, 2 Samuel 17:20, Psalm 143:9, Revelation 6:15-17).

questions.question: How did Joshua ensure the five kings could not escape from the cave?
options: Roll great stones upon the mouth of the cave and set men to guard it
Seal the cave with a curse
Block the cave with wood and fire
Surround the cave with an army
questions.correctAnswer: Roll great stones upon the mouth of the cave and set men to guard it
questions.explanation: Joshua commanded to roll stones upon the cave’s mouth and place guards to secure the kings (Joshua 10:18), symbolizing divine judgment and the certainty of punishment (Genesis 4:11-12, 2 Kings 23:19, Matthew 27:60, Revelation 20:3).

questions.question: What did Joshua command to be done to the five kings after bringing them out of the cave?
options: Put their feet upon their necks and then smite and hang them on five trees
Release them on condition of peace
Imprison them for life
Make them slaves to Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Put their feet upon their necks and then smite and hang them on five trees
questions.explanation: Joshua called for the captains to put their feet on the kings’ necks as a symbol of victory, then he killed them and hung them on trees (Joshua 10:24-26). This act shows God’s judgment on enemies of His covenant people (Deuteronomy 21:22-23, Psalm 37:34, Luke 13:28, Revelation 20:4).

questions.question: What theological truth is underscored by the fact that all the kings and their cities were utterly destroyed?
options: God’s judgment is thorough and just
War is always justified in Scripture
Cities represent human pride and must fall
Victory depends on numerical superiority
questions.correctAnswer: God’s judgment is thorough and just
questions.explanation: The complete destruction of kings and cities shows God’s righteous judgment against sin and opposition to His covenant people (Joshua 10:28-39). This reflects the holiness and justice of God (Genesis 15:16, Deuteronomy 9:4-5, Ezekiel 25:17, Romans 12:19).

questions.question: What does the sending of hailstones by the LORD during the battle indicate about God’s providence?
options: God controls natural elements to execute judgment
Hailstones were a natural weather event coinciding with battle
It was a punishment for Israel’s enemies’ sins only
It showed God’s wrath was limited to the Amorites
questions.correctAnswer: God controls natural elements to execute judgment
questions.explanation: The LORD cast down great stones from heaven killing more than the sword (Joshua 10:11), revealing God’s control over nature to fulfill His purposes (Psalm 18:11-13, Exodus 9:23-24, Nahum 1:3, Revelation 16:21).

questions.question: How does Joshua 10 demonstrate the relationship between divine sovereignty and human responsibility?
options: Joshua and Israel actively fought while God guaranteed victory
God fought alone without human involvement
Israel won by their own strength without God’s help
God’s sovereignty removes all human responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: Joshua and Israel actively fought while God guaranteed victory
questions.explanation: Joshua led the army in battle (Joshua 10:7, 9, 19), yet God promised deliverance and fought for Israel (Joshua 10:8, 14). This shows cooperative divine-human action in salvation history (Exodus 14:15-16, Judges 7:7, Philippians 2:12-13, Hebrews 4:16).

questions.question: What does the repeated phrase 'he left none remaining' throughout the chapter teach about God’s holiness?
options: God’s holiness requires complete removal of evil
God is indifferent to human life
God’s grace is shown by sparing many
God’s judgment is always temporal
questions.correctAnswer: God’s holiness requires complete removal of evil
questions.explanation: The total destruction reflects God's holy intolerance of sin and judgment on evil (Joshua 10:28-39). This aligns with biblical teaching on holiness and judgment (Leviticus 20:7, Habakkuk 1:13, Hebrews 12:29, Revelation 21:27).

questions.question: How does the chapter illustrate the theme of God’s faithfulness to His covenant promises?
options: God fought for Israel and gave them victory over their enemies
Israel succeeded because of their military strategy
The Amorite kings surrendered peacefully
The land was conquered through alliances
questions.correctAnswer: God fought for Israel and gave them victory over their enemies
questions.explanation: God’s promise to give the land to Israel was fulfilled by His direct intervention and victories (Joshua 10:14, 42). This is consistent with God’s covenant faithfulness throughout Scripture (Genesis 15:18, Exodus 6:7, Deuteronomy 7:9, 2 Corinthians 1:20).

questions.question: What Christological foreshadowing might be seen in the LORD fighting for Israel and extending the day?
options: Christ as the divine Warrior who conquers sin and death
Christ as a political king establishing earthly kingdoms
Christ as a teacher of morality
Christ as a passive observer
questions.correctAnswer: Christ as the divine Warrior who conquers sin and death
questions.explanation: The LORD fighting for Israel and controlling time to ensure victory prefigures Christ’s ultimate victory over evil (Revelation 19:11-16, Colossians 2:15, Hebrews 2:14-15, 1 Corinthians 15:25).

questions.question: What does the repeated return to Gilgal after battles signify in the theological narrative?
options: Gilgal as a center of covenant renewal and dependence on God
Gilgal as a military base for Israel
Gilgal as a place of economic trade
Gilgal as a city of refuge
questions.correctAnswer: Gilgal as a center of covenant renewal and dependence on God
questions.explanation: Joshua’s return to Gilgal (Joshua 10:15, 43) indicates a pattern of returning to a sacred place symbolizing covenant relationship and reliance on God’s guidance (Joshua 5:9-10, Deut 27:4-8, 1 Sam 7:5-6, Psalm 132:13-14).
